title: How to Make Paint Thicker in a Few Easy Steps

steps.title: Buy a thickening agent.
steps.content: Buy a thickening agent. You can buy a thickening agent for your paint from a local home improvement store. Most thickening agents for latex paint are made with water-soluble hydroxyethyl cellulose which works well with the latex. [2] X Research source Make sure the thickening agent says it works with latex paint.

steps.title: Add the thickening agent to the paint.
steps.content: Add the thickening agent to the paint. Read the directions on the bottle of thickening agent to find out how much to use. Typically you will add it by the tablespoon depending on how much paint you have. [3] X Research source For the best result, add a smaller amount than called for, and then slowly add more until you get the thickness you need. Adding more than the manufacturer’s recommended amount can cause the paint to crack and peel when applied to the wall.

steps.title: Stir the paint.
steps.content: Stir the paint. Use a paint stick to slowly stir the thickening agent into the paint. The paint will thicken as you stir. If the paint still isn’t thick enough, add more thickening agent in small amounts as you stir.

steps.title: Test the paint.
steps.content: Test the paint. Paint a small part of the wall to test the thickness of the paint. Let this paint dry completely before checking the results. The paint should not have cracks or be peeling in any way. If the paint looks great and has an even color, you can finish painting the rest of the wall.

steps.title: Gather the materials needed.
steps.content: Gather the materials needed. You will need cornstarch, water, a pot, tempera paint, and a sealable container to make your paint thicker. Have these materials ready when you begin this project.

steps.title: Heat cornstarch and water.
steps.content: Heat cornstarch and water. Add 4 teaspoons of cornstarch to 3 cups of water in a pot. Mix them together until they’re combined. Heat the mixture on low heat stirring frequently. Stir until the cornstarch has dissolved and the mixture becomes smooth and thick.

steps.title: Cool the mixture.
steps.content: Cool the mixture. When the mixture is smooth and thick, remove it from the heat and allow it to cool. Stir the mixture after it has completely cooled.

steps.title: Add the cornstarch mixture to the paint.
steps.content: Add the cornstarch mixture to the paint. Slowly add the cornstarch mixture to the tempera paint stirring occasionally. Use a spoon to add the cornstarch mixture or slowly pour it into the paint. Add the cornstarch mixture until the paint reaches the thickness you desire.

steps.title: Store the extra cornstarch mixture.
steps.content: Store the extra cornstarch mixture. Use a sealable container to store any extra cornstarch mixture. You can use the cornstarch thickening agent to make tempera paint thicker in the future.

steps.title: Purchase a medium to add to your paints.
steps.content: Purchase a medium to add to your paints. Many art stores carry house brand paint additives that are designed to be mixed with acrylic paints. Liquitex and Golden are two popular manufactures of painting medium additives. Look for a matte or gel medium that dries clear to maintain the color of your paints. [4] X Research source Mix a small amount of the medium with your paint. Stir the paint and test the thickness on a small sample paper. Blow dry the sample and observe the color and thickness of your brush stroke. Add more medium if you desire a thicker paint.

steps.title: Use a texture gel to add body to your paint.
steps.content: Use a texture gel to add body to your paint. Many gel compounds contain additives to mimic sand or stucco. Combine the texture gel with your paint to give the paint a textured feel. [5] X Research source You can experiment with adding sand or sawdust in small amounts to add additional texture.

steps.title: Mix modeling paste into the paint.
steps.content: Mix modeling paste into the paint. Work a small amount of modeling paste to add thickness to your paints that will show up in your brushstrokes. [6] X Research source Modeling paste dries white and may alter the colors of your paints.

steps.title: Combine beeswax and turpentine to create a paste.
steps.content: Combine beeswax and turpentine to create a paste. Mix 1 part beeswax with 3 parts turpentine. Stir the turpentine into the beeswax until an even mixture is formed. [7] X Expert Source Kelly Medford Professional Artist Expert Interview. 10 March 2021

steps.title: Work the paste into your paint to achieve the desired thickness.
steps.content: Work the paste into your paint to achieve the desired thickness. Mix the paint and paste directly on your palette.

steps.title: Use a commercial paint medium.
steps.content: Use a commercial paint medium. Visit your local art store and browse the selection of oil paint mediums. There are many commercial paint mediums that add texture or thickness to paints. Choose your medium based on the look you desire for your painting; some mediums can change the gloss or color of the paint. Combine the medium with the paint according to the package instructions. Opt for an alkyd medium to help your paint dry quicker. [8] X Expert Source Kelly Medford Professional Artist Expert Interview. 10 March 2021 Adjust the amount of medium you add to your paints until you reach the desired consistency.
